comments_since_last_sample.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

Speak to a therapist or counsellor. Someone who can help you talk out your reasoning and get to the root of why you feel this way about yourself. It really does help as they have the experience to ask the right questions to help you realise why you're so hard on yourself and how to build up your confidence and dig yourself out of that hole. 

You need to be really open to it though. Therapy is only effective if you're willing to be honest with yourself. This type of self-reflection journey is often rough and painful, but when you come out the other side, it's wonderful.

The solution is simple but difficult.

And as it's an advisory Reddit, I'll skip the validation.

See a therapist. Go to a self defense class. 

Many will say "but she's a girl that diff!".

IT'S NOT.

Here is a link to free self-help workbooks: https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself

I feel for you, for your intense feelings of anxiety and the pain it’s causing you. I recommend you take a look at the body dysmorphia section too, and see if any of it seems similar to your experience. You may have flaws, but you may also be so focused on the flaws that fixing them will only give you temporary relief, because you will begin to fixate on the next flaw once the first one is remedied. Your pain is real, and you have a right to take steps to improve your appearance to feel more confident. Sometimes it really is the flaw holding you back, and after it’s fixed, you feel great long term. If you improve your appearance but still feel this intense anxiety, and think every look means someone noticed your flaws, I would recommend working with a counselor who understands body dysmorphia. 

Once you are out of school, life gets easier. You’ll have more control of who you spend time with. You won’t be stuck in a building with bullies anymore. And, you never have to see any of these people again after graduating. Keep in mind that if a bully knows your insecurities, they will pick on you for it, even if they don’t really see your flaws themselves or really think the flaw is a big deal. Their goal is to hurt you, so they’ll say whatever hurts the most, even if they don’t believe it themselves.

Do your parents realize the agony this is causing you? Do they know you are crying in the bathroom? I would tell them these things, if you haven’t already. Do they disagree with you about the severity of your flaws? This might be a clue that your perspective might be distorted. Would they let you consult with an esthetician to see what her opinion is, and to explore age-appropriate or lower-cost options?

Hey mate, beauty is subjective and people can be assholes. 

LPT: 
Hang in there. School can be a hard time. People haven't grown up yet. Some people never will. 

Pick something you like about life and focus on that. Breathe. 
Take time away from socials, as much as possible. 
Try join a group of something your interested in. You might make some positive friends, who enjoy the things you do. 

The sun is on the other end, weather the storm. 
Life gets better, just give it some time. You will see :)

No idea how old you are, but this will get better as you get older. Trust me, been there!

The best advice I can give you is going to sound pretty harsh, but when you think people are looking at you and judging you etc, they probably are, but not for very long. They don’t go home and dwell on it, you are just a side character in the shit show that is there life, same way they are a side character in yours. 

You might think you are ugly or fat or whatever, but I promise you, you’re worst critic is you. 

School can be vicious, people can be dicks. You be you and screw anyone who tries to tell you otherwise. 

All of this sounds great, but it is going to be hard to implement. Just think about how long you judge others shortcomings and apply that thought process in reverse. 

Good luck!

The best way to become confident is to pretend you are until it rubs off on yourself and you eventually just become actually confident. 

It's tough but if you can hold yourself to it you'll find yourself being much more confident naturally. 

Also important: do your best to love the skin you're in. Once you're older you can get work done if you still want to, but you may find that behaving confidently and trying to find comfort in what you were born with could lead you to not even wanting to change in that way.

Have you ever heard the phrase, “Fake it ‘till you make it”? Confidence is one of those things you can fake until you have it. When I was in high school I was considered bubbly and very confident, and it was 100% fake. On the inside I was super shy, introverted, and thought all the bad things about myself, and I probably would have stayed that way were it not for the fateful day I ditched school and missed the city bus back home. I ended up talking to some old woman about all sorts of things (I was about 14) and one of the things that stuck with me was the “Fake it till you make it” thing. 

At home and in privacy I worked on myself, because like you I was super sensitive. The wrong look and BAM tears. I hated it so much. So at home without anyone looking at me, or making fun at me, I could just work on my self esteem and anything else I wanted to improve. 

In the real world I had to fake it. I didn’t want to be miserable shy mess in public, so I pretended to be so much more put together than I was. 

It worked. 

It took a long time but eventually the faking of confidence showed me things I could only see by putting my shyness and low self esteem aside. Eventually the confidence stayed. It’s about perspective with confidence but again that won’t make sense until it does. 

This is what worked for me in my teenage days, I hope it helps you! And whether you are ugly, pretty, weird, it doesn’t matter, you’re the only you that you’ve got so you may as well enjoy the ride.

From really overweight to Fitness model during my teenage years, I can tell you one thing: some people will always criticize you. No matter what body you have. Too fat? You’re a lazy person. Too muscular? Ew, ugly. Other boys are jealous and aggressive. So, pro tip: don’t give a f*ck, live your life and enjoy it to the fullest. Changing your appearance won’t help that much, it’s all in your mind. A confident person brightens the room and feel more beautiful. You have to work on it. Good luck! :)

Hi, I’m sorry you’re feeling this way. Many times, peoples thoughts of others are reflections of themselves. Even the most conventionally attractive people have those who will find something about them to bash on. The important thing to remember is that they have no bearing on the person you actually are. If you are feeling down on yourself in your own right, there are a few things you can do to help build self esteem. First, find things you like to do and do them! You will meet like minded people this way, and having friends who care about you and support you is a big help when considering your mental well-being. You might also get very good at these things, and having a skill l, or something you’re good at, will allow you a sense of pride in the work that you put in. Do things to improve upon yourself. Exercise is a great place to start. It will give you a sense of purpose, an improved mental state, and you may even improve your looks from doing so (this shouldn’t be your sole focus, but it’s a nice side effect. Who doesn’t like to be in shape?). Also, realize that your school aged years are a temporary part of life, and while it can be a very difficult time, as kids can be pretty brutal to one another, it won’t always be this way. Focus on your strengths. You must have things you consider your strengths, so spend more time thinking about them, and focus less on what you perceive as your shortcomings. If you do feel your thoughts drifting towards a negative place, use that as a source of motivation, rather than allowing it to def you down. I hope this advice helps, even a little bit, and I hope that you realize that you are valuable and loved, and even if you don’t think so at times, that you have a very bright life ahead of you, if you allow yourself to it.

LPT - be yourself to the fullest. Ugly, Hot, Fat, or Skinny. People are attracted to honest presentations of self. Do the things you enjoy doing. If you are still in school practice what you love now. As soon as school is over you can really focus on your loves and people will ultimately find your passions more attractive than anything superficial. Don’t live for other people, repel people that don’t accept you for you.

Have you ever heard the phrase, “Fake it ‘till you make it”? Confidence is one of those things you can fake until you have it. When I was in high school I was considered bubbly and very confident, and it was 100% fake. On the inside I was super shy, introverted, and thought all the bad things about myself, and I probably would have stayed that way were it not for the fateful day I ditched school and missed the city bus back home. I ended up talking to some old woman about all sorts of things (I was about 14) and one of the things that stuck with me was the “Fake it till you make it” thing. 

At home and in privacy I worked on myself, because like you I was super sensitive. The wrong look and BAM tears. I hated it so much. So at home without anyone looking at me, or making fun at me, I could just work on my self esteem and anything else I wanted to improve. 

In the real world I had to fake it. I didn’t want to be miserable shy mess in public, so I pretended to be so much more put together than I was. 

It worked. 

It took a long time but eventually the faking of confidence showed me things I could only see by putting my shyness and low self esteem aside. Eventually the confidence stayed. It’s about perspective with confidence but again that won’t make sense until it does. 

This is what worked for me in my teenage days, I hope it helps you! And whether you are ugly, pretty, weird, it doesn’t matter, you’re the only you that you’ve got so you may as well enjoy the ride.

No idea how old you are, but this will get better as you get older. Trust me, been there!

The best advice I can give you is going to sound pretty harsh, but when you think people are looking at you and judging you etc, they probably are, but not for very long. They don’t go home and dwell on it, you are just a side character in the shit show that is there life, same way they are a side character in yours. 

You might think you are ugly or fat or whatever, but I promise you, you’re worst critic is you. 

School can be vicious, people can be dicks. You be you and screw anyone who tries to tell you otherwise. 

All of this sounds great, but it is going to be hard to implement. Just think about how long you judge others shortcomings and apply that thought process in reverse. 

Good luck!

Even the most conventionally attractive people have those who will find something about them to bash on. The important thing to remember is that they have no bearing on the person you actually are. If you are feeling down on yourself in your own right, there are a few things you can do to help build self esteem. First, find things you like to do and do them! You will meet like minded people this way, and having friends who care about you and support you is a big help when considering your mental well-being. You might also get very good at these things, and having a skill l, or something you’re good at, will allow you a sense of pride in the work that you put in. Do things to improve upon yourself. Exercise is a great place to start. It will give you a sense of purpose, an improved mental state, and you may even improve your looks from doing so (this shouldn’t be your sole focus, but it’s a nice side effect. Who doesn’t like to be in shape?). Also, realize that your school aged years are a temporary part of life, and while it can be a very difficult time, as kids can be pretty brutal to one another, it won’t always be this way. I hope this advice helps, even a little bit, and I hope that you realize that you are valuable and loved, and even if you don’t think so at times, that you have a very bright life ahead of you, if you allow yourself to it.

top_comments_best.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

Have you ever heard the phrase, “Fake it ‘till you make it”? Confidence is one of those things you can fake until you have it. When I was in high school I was considered bubbly and very confident, and it was 100% fake. On the inside I was super shy, introverted, and thought all the bad things about myself, and I probably would have stayed that way were it not for the fateful day I ditched school and missed the city bus back home. I ended up talking to some old woman about all sorts of things (I was about 14) and one of the things that stuck with me was the “Fake it till you make it” thing. 

At home and in privacy I worked on myself, because like you I was super sensitive. The wrong look and BAM tears. I hated it so much. So at home without anyone looking at me, or making fun at me, I could just work on my self esteem and anything else I wanted to improve. 

In the real world I had to fake it. I didn’t want to be miserable shy mess in public, so I pretended to be so much more put together than I was. 

It worked. 

It took a long time but eventually the faking of confidence showed me things I could only see by putting my shyness and low self esteem aside. Eventually the confidence stayed. It’s about perspective with confidence but again that won’t make sense until it does. 

This is what worked for me in my teenage days, I hope it helps you! And whether you are ugly, pretty, weird, it doesn’t matter, you’re the only you that you’ve got so you may as well enjoy the ride.

No idea how old you are, but this will get better as you get older. Trust me, been there!

The best advice I can give you is going to sound pretty harsh, but when you think people are looking at you and judging you etc, they probably are, but not for very long. They don’t go home and dwell on it, you are just a side character in the shit show that is there life, same way they are a side character in yours. 

You might think you are ugly or fat or whatever, but I promise you, you’re worst critic is you. 

School can be vicious, people can be dicks. You be you and screw anyone who tries to tell you otherwise. 

All of this sounds great, but it is going to be hard to implement. Just think about how long you judge others shortcomings and apply that thought process in reverse. 

Good luck!

Hi, I’m sorry you’re feeling this way. Many times, peoples thoughts of others are reflections of themselves. Even the most conventionally attractive people have those who will find something about them to bash on. The important thing to remember is that they have no bearing on the person you actually are. If you are feeling down on yourself in your own right, there are a few things you can do to help build self esteem. First, find things you like to do and do them! You will meet like minded people this way, and having friends who care about you and support you is a big help when considering your mental well-being. You might also get very good at these things, and having a skill l, or something you’re good at, will allow you a sense of pride in the work that you put in. Do things to improve upon yourself. Exercise is a great place to start. It will give you a sense of purpose, an improved mental state, and you may even improve your looks from doing so (this shouldn’t be your sole focus, but it’s a nice side effect. Who doesn’t like to be in shape?). Also, realize that your school aged years are a temporary part of life, and while it can be a very difficult time, as kids can be pretty brutal to one another, it won’t always be this way. Focus on your strengths. You must have things you consider your strengths, so spend more time thinking about them, and focus less on what you perceive as your shortcomings. If you do feel your thoughts drifting towards a negative place, use that as a source of motivation, rather than allowing it to def you down. I hope this advice helps, even a little bit, and I hope that you realize that you are valuable and loved, and even if you don’t think so at times, that you have a very bright life ahead of you, if you allow yourself to it.

LPT - be yourself to the fullest. Ugly, Hot, Fat, or Skinny. People are attracted to honest presentations of self. Do the things you enjoy doing. If you are still in school practice what you love now. As soon as school is over you can really focus on your loves and people will ultimately find your passions more attractive than anything superficial. Don’t live for other people, repel people that don’t accept you for you.
